thread.title: Melbourne's bus system set for overhaul as Government opens up contracts - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Melbourne's bus system set for overhaul as Government opens up contracts - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

title: Melbourne's bus system set for overhaul as Government opens up contracts - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Melbourne's bus system set for overhaul as Government opens up contracts Posted February 16, 2017 08:45:08 Map: Melbourne 3000 
A push for a "modern and more flexible" bus system is behind a decision to open up contracts for the declining Melbourne network, the Victorian Government says. 
The bus network's service contracts expire next year and the Andrews Government has opened up 12 of the 13 contracts. 
Many of the contracts have been held by the same private operators for decades. 
The changes will be introduced over the next 10 years, the Government said. 
Minister for Public Transport Jacinta Allan said the current contracts did not match up to the city's recent growth and limited the amount of services the Government could run. 
"They don't necessarily reflect the needs of people or what passengers are looking for," she said. 
"What we're wanting to do is put in place contract arrangements that provide more flexibility, give the Government capacity to provide more bus services, particularly to new areas, growing areas in Melbourne," she said. 
While tram and train services are jam-packed, bus usage has declined over the past three years. 
Ms Allan said despite that, buses were a crucial service for some parts of Melbourne. 
"Obviously they can go where trains and trams can't," she said. 
"We want to address that because they are important for some communities, they're the only kind of public transport they can access."
